previous_headings: Formatting statistical values > Central tendency and error
title: formatstats
text: Often, need include simple descriptive statistics documents, measures central tendency error. formatstats includes suite functions can calculate different summary measures central tendency (mean median) error (confidence interval, standard error, standard deviation, interquartile range) numeric data vector. base function format_meanerror(), can specify central tendency summary argument error error argument. instance, format_meanerror(vec, summary = "mean", error = "se") calculates mean standard error. formatstats includes number wrapper functions cover common measures central tendency error including: format_meanci() format_meanse() format_meansd() format_medianiqr() don’t want include error, use format_mean() format_median().

previous_headings: Formatting statistical values > Central tendency and error
title: formatstats
text: addition calculating values directly vectors, functions can format already-calculated measures. already mean error calculated, just pass vector central tendency, lower error limit, upper error limit values argument format . instance, format_meanci(values = c(12.5, 11.2, 13.7)) produces M = 12.5, 95% CI [11.2, 13.7]. Make sure pass arguments order, function checks whether send argument less equal first third greater equal first.

previous_headings: Formatting statistical values > Central tendency and error
title: formatstats
text: functions can control many aspects formatting values labels summary statistics. Digits decimal controlled digits (default 1). meanlabel argument defines whether default abbreviation used (“M” “Mdn”), full word (“Mean” “Median”), label provided. can italicized italics argument, subscripts can included subscript argument, units added units argument. Error can displayed number different ways. Setting display argument "limits" (default) includes upper lower limits brackets. intervals rather limits preferred, can appended mean/median ± using "pm" parentheses "par". Error displayed display = "none". presence error label controlled logical argument errorlabel. set FALSE, error label included. confidence intervals, cilevel argument takes numeric scalar 0-1 define confidence level.

title: formatstats
text: P-values pretty easy format format_p(). digits argument controls number digits decimal, value lower, p < used. Unfortunately, APA style involves lopping leading zero p-values, setting pzero  = TRUE turns silly setting. p-value label controlled label, user can specify exact label text. default, lower case, italicized p. Non-italicized can defined italics = FALSE. P-value labels can omitted setting label = "".

title: formatstats
text: format_bf() function can either format vector numeric values extract format Bayes factors BFBayesFactor object {BayesFactor} package. Bayes factors standardized formatted. One issue Bayes factors can referenced either alternative hypothesis (H1) null hypothesis (H0). Also, ratio, digits decimal important 1 1. respond digits issue, format_bf() function controls digits Bayes factor less 1 (digits1) separately greater 1 (digits2). fact, defaults different two arguments. , Bayes factors can large small evidence strongly favors one hypothesis another. Therefore, cutoff argument set threshold (1/cutoff) returned value truncated (e.g., BF > 1000). default label Bayes factors BF10. text label can changed label argument, setting label = "" omits label. Italics can removed italics = FALSE, subscript can set 01 (subscript = "01") removed (subscript = "").

title: formatstats
text: Running statistical test R typically returns list lots information test, often including things like statistical test values p-values. aim set functions extract format statistics suite commonly used statistical objects (correlation t-tests).

title: formatstats
text: format_corr() function inputs objects returned cor.test() function detects whether object Pearson, Kendall, Spearman correlation. reports formats appropriate correlation coefficient p-value. Let’s start creating different correlations. Pearson correlations, get correlation coefficient confidence intervals. Since Spearman Kendall correlations non-parametric, confidence intervals returned. Confidence intervals can omitted Pearson correlations setting ci = FALSE. Format number digits coefficients digits digits p-values pdigits. Include leading zeros coefficients p-values pzero = TRUE. Remove italics italics = FALSE.
code: mpg_disp_corr_pearson <- cor.test(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$disp, method = "pearson") mpg_disp_corr_spearman <- cor.test(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$disp, method = "spearman", exact = FALSE) mpg_disp_corr_kendall <- cor.test(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$disp, method = "kendall", exact = FALSE)

title: formatstats
text: format_ttest() function inputs objects returned t.test() wilcox.test() functions detects whether object Student’s Wilcoxon t-test, including one-sample, independent-sample, paired-sample versions. reports formats mean value (mean difference), confidence intervals mean value/difference, appropriate test statistic, degrees freedom (parametric tests), p-value. Let’s start creating different t-tests Student’s t-tests, get mean value difference confidence intervals. Means confidence intervals can omitted setting full = FALSE. Format number digits coefficients digits digits p-values pdigits. Include leading zeros coefficients p-values pzero = TRUE. Remove italics italics = FALSE.
code: mpg_disp_ttest_gear_carb <- t.test(mtcars$gear, mtcars$carb) mpg_disp_ttest_gear_carb_paired <- t.test(mtcars$gear, mtcars$carb, paired = TRUE) mpg_disp_ttest_gear_carb_onesample <- t.test(mtcars$gear, mu = 4) mpg_disp_wtest_gear_carb <- wilcox.test(mtcars$gear, mtcars$carb, exact = FALSE) mpg_disp_wtest_gear_carb_paired <- wilcox.test(mtcars$gear, mtcars$carb, paired = TRUE, exact = FALSE) mpg_disp_wtest_gear_carb_onesample <- wilcox.test(mtcars$gear, mu = 4, exact = FALSE)

title: formatstats
text: addition formatting specific statistics, package can format numbers generally. format_num() function controls general formatting numbers digits digits presence leading zero pzero. large small values, using scientific notation may useful way format numbers. format_scientific() function converts scientific notation, offering control number digits well whether output type Markdown LaTeX.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Jeffrey R. Stevens. Author, maintainer, copyright holder.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Stevens J (2024). formatstats: Format Print Statistical Output. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://jeffreyrstevens.github.io/formatstats/, https://github.com/JeffreyRStevens/formatstats.
code: @Manual{,   title = {formatstats: Format and Print Statistical Output},   author = {Jeffrey R. Stevens},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://jeffreyrstevens.github.io/formatstats/},   url = {https://github.com/JeffreyRStevens/formatstats}, }

title: Format and Print Statistical Output
text: goal formatstats provide functions flexibly format statistical output way can inserted R Markdown Quarto documents. analogous apa_print() functions {papaja} package, functions formatstats can print Markdown LaTeX syntax. output document PDF, doesn’t matter. output document Word document (required many journal publishers), Markdown syntax generates editable output instead image output. default style statistical output follows American Psychological Association style, many defaults can -ridden flexibly format output.

title: Format and Print Statistical Output
text: can install development version formatstats GitHub :
code: # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("JeffreyRStevens/formatstats")

title: Format and Print Statistical Output
text: example, ’ll create correlation mtcars data set. Now can apply format_corr() function cars_corr create Markdown-formatted character string statistical results. can embed inline R Markdown code generate results.
code: library(formatstats) (cars_corr <- cor.test(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$disp)) #>  #>  Pearson's product-moment correlation #>  #> data:  mtcars$mpg and mtcars$disp #> t = -8.7472, df = 30, p-value = 9.38e-10 #> alternative hypothesis: true correlation is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>  -0.9233594 -0.7081376 #> sample estimates: #>        cor  #> -0.8475514

title: Format and Print Statistical Output
text: Fuel efficiency engine displacement highly correlated (`r format_corr(cars_corr)`).

title: Format and Print Statistical Output
text: Fuel efficiency engine displacement highly correlated (r = -.85, 95% CI [-0.92, -0.71], p < .001).

title: Format and Print Statistical Output
text: can also alter output allow formatting. instance, may like APA’s silly rule remove leading zeros value exceed 1 (like correlations p-values). may want include confidence limits around correlation coefficient. Finally, maybe don’t want statistics labels italicized.

title: Format and Print Statistical Output
text: Fuel efficiency engine displacement highly correlated (`r format_corr(cars_corr, pzero = TRUE, ci = FALSE, italics = FALSE)`).

title: Format and Print Statistical Output
text: Fuel efficiency engine displacement highly correlated (r = -0.85, p < 0.001).

title: Format and Print Statistical Output
text: Correlations (output cor.test(), including Pearson’s, Kendall’s, Spearman’s correlations) Student t-tests Wilcoxon rank sum signed rank tests (output t.test() wilcox.test(), including one-sample, two-sample independent, paired tests) Means error (calculates vector uses vector mean error interval mean, lower error limit, upper error limit) P-values Bayes factors (output BayesFactor objects scalar number) Scientific notation numbers

title: Format and Print Statistical Output
text: cite formatstats, use: Stevens, Jeffrey R. (2024). formatstats: Format print statistical output. (version 0.0.0.9000) https://github.com/JeffreyRStevens/formatstats

title: Format and Print Statistical Output
text: papaja - package uses apa_print() function convert number R statistical objects R Markdown output. However, outputs LaTeX syntax generates APA formatted output minimal flexibility alter output. apa - package also converts R statistical objects R Markdown output. allows output format Markdown, also generates APA formatted output minimal flexibility alter output.

title: Format Bayes factors — format_bf
text: format_bf() can input either BayesFactor object vectors Bayes factor values. default, function rounds Bayes factors greater 1 one decimal place Bayes factors less 1 two decimal places. Values greater 1000 less 1/1000 formatted using scientific notation. Cutoffs can set format values greater less cutoffs (e.g., BF > 1000 BF < 0.001). Numbers digits, cutoffs, italics, label subscripts customizable.

title: Format Bayes factors — format_bf
code: format_bf(   x,   digits1 = 1,   digits2 = 2,   cutoff = NULL,   label = "BF",   italics = TRUE,   subscript = "10",   type = "md" )

title: Format Bayes factors — format_bf
text: x BayesFactor object vector numeric Bayes factor values digits1 Number digits decimal Bayes factors > 1 digits2 Number digits decimal Bayes factors < 1 cutoff Cutoff using _BF_~10~ > <cutoff> _BF_~10~ < 1 / <cutoff> (value must > 1) label Character string label Bayes factor. Default BF. Set label = "" return just formatted Bayes factor value label operator (=, <, >) italics Logical whether label italicized (BF BF) subscript Subscript include BF label ("10", "01", "" subscript) type Type formatting ("md" = markdown, "latex" = LaTeX)

title: Format Bayes factors — format_bf
text: character string includes label (default BF~10~) Bayes factor formatted Markdown LaTeX. Bayes factor cutoff, _BF_~10~ > <cutoff> _BF_~10~ < 1 / <cutoff> used.

title: Format Bayes factors — format_bf
code: # Format Bayes factors > 1 format_bf(12.4444) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 12.4" # Bayes factors > 1000 will use scientific notation format_bf(1244.44) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 1.2×10^3^" # Control digits for Bayes factors > 1 with digits1 format_bf(1244.44, digits1 = 3) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 1.244×10^3^" # Control cutoff for output format_bf(1244.44, cutoff = 10000) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 1244.4" # Format Bayes factors < 1 format_bf(0.111) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 0.11" # Bayes factors < 0.001 will use scientific notation format_bf(0.0001) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 1.0×10^-4^" # Control digits for Bayes factors < 1 with digits2 format_bf(0.111, digits2 = 3) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ = 0.111" # Control cutoff for output format_bf(0.001, cutoff = 100) #> [1] "_BF_~10~ < 0.01" # Return only Bayes factor value (no label) format_bf(12.4444, label = "") #> [1] "12.4"

title: Format correlation statistics — format_corr
text: format_corr() can format correlation statistics generated cor.test() output. detects whether object Pearson, Kendall, Spearman correlation reports appropriate correlation label (r, τ, ρ). default output APA formatted, numbers digits, leading zeros, presence confidence intervals, italics customizable.

title: Format correlation statistics — format_corr
code: format_corr(   x,   digits = 2,   pdigits = 3,   pzero = FALSE,   ci = TRUE,   italics = TRUE,   type = "md" )

title: Format correlation statistics — format_corr
text: x Correlation object digits Number digits decimal means, confidence intervals, correlation coefficients pdigits Number digits decimal p-values, ranging 1-5 (also controls cutoff small p-values) pzero Logical indicator whether include leading zero p-values ci Logical indicator whether print 95% confidence intervals italics Logical whether p label italicized type Type formatting ("md" = markdown, "latex" = LaTeX)

title: Format correlation statistics — format_corr
text: character string statistical information formatted Markdown LaTeX.

title: Format correlation statistics — format_corr
code: # Prepare data mtcars_corr <- cor.test(mtcars$mpg, mtcars$disp) # Print statistics format_corr(mtcars_corr) #> [1] "_r_ = -.85, 95% CI [-0.92, -0.71], _p_ < .001" # Change digits format_corr(mtcars_corr, digits = 3) #> [1] "_r_ = -.848, 95% CI [-0.923, -0.708], _p_ < .001" # Change cutoff digits for p-value format_corr(mtcars_corr, pdigits = 2) #> [1] "_r_ = -.85, 95% CI [-0.92, -0.71], _p_ < .01" # Add leading zero to p-value and don't print confidence intervals format_corr(mtcars_corr, pzero = TRUE, ci = FALSE) #> [1] "_r_ = -0.85, _p_ < 0.001"

what: Calculate and format mean and error — format_meanerror
title: Calculate and format mean and error — format_meanerror
text: format_meanerror() general function allows either automatically calculate mean/median measure error data vector specify already calculated mean/median either error interval error limits. Error measures include confidence intervals, standard deviation, standard error mean. specific function formats means error measures using APA (7th edition) style. format_meanci(), format_meansd(), format_meanse(), format_medianiqr() wrappers around format_meanerror() specific error measures default style. just format mean median error, use format_mean() format_median(), wrappers around format_meanerror() drop error measure. measures ignore NAs.

title: Calculate and format mean and error — format_meanerror
code: format_meanerror(   x = NULL,   summary = "mean",   error = "ci",   values = NULL,   digits = 1,   meanlabel = "abbr",   italics = TRUE,   subscript = NULL,   units = NULL,   display = "limits",   cilevel = 0.95,   errorlabel = TRUE,   type = "md" )  format_mean(   x = NULL,   summary = "mean",   values = NULL,   digits = 1,   meanlabel = "abbr",   italics = TRUE,   subscript = NULL,   units = NULL,   display = "none",   type = "md" )  format_meanci(   x = NULL,   summary = "mean",   error = "ci",   values = NULL,   digits = 1,   meanlabel = "abbr",   italics = TRUE,   subscript = NULL,   units = NULL,   display = "limits",   cilevel = 0.95,   errorlabel = TRUE,   type = "md" )  format_meanse(   x = NULL,   summary = "mean",   error = "se",   values = NULL,   digits = 1,   meanlabel = "abbr",   italics = TRUE,   subscript = NULL,   units = NULL,   display = "par",   errorlabel = TRUE,   type = "md" )  format_meansd(   x = NULL,   summary = "mean",   error = "sd",   values = NULL,   digits = 1,   meanlabel = "abbr",   italics = TRUE,   subscript = NULL,   units = NULL,   display = "par",   errorlabel = TRUE,   type = "md" )  format_median(   x = NULL,   summary = "median",   values = NULL,   digits = 1,   meanlabel = "abbr",   italics = TRUE,   subscript = NULL,   units = NULL,   display = "none",   type = "md" )  format_medianiqr(   x = NULL,   summary = "median",   error = "iqr",   values = NULL,   digits = 1,   meanlabel = "abbr",   italics = TRUE,   subscript = NULL,   units = NULL,   display = "par",   errorlabel = TRUE,   type = "md" )

title: Calculate and format mean and error — format_meanerror
text: x Numeric vector data calculate mean error summary Character vector specifying summary measure central tendency ("mean" = mean, "median" = median) error Character vector specifying error type ("ci" = confidence interval, "se" = standard error mean, "sd" = standard deviation, "iqr" = interquartile range) values Numeric vector mean interval mean lower upper limits digits Number digits decimal means error meanlabel Formatting mean label ("abbr" = M, "word" = Mean, "none" = label) italics Logical whether mean label italicized subscript Character string include subscript mean label units Character string gives units include mean value display Character vector specifying display error ("limits" = [lower limit, upper limit], "pm" = ±interval, "par" = (interval), "none" = display error) cilevel Numeric scalar 0-1 defining confidence level (defaults 0.95) errorlabel Logical whether error label (e.g., 95% CI) included type Type formatting ("md" = markdown, "latex" = LaTeX)

title: Calculate and format mean and error — format_meanerror
text: character string mean error formatted Markdown LaTeX. return mean (error), set display = "none".

title: Calculate and format mean and error — format_meanerror
code: # Print mean and 95% confidence limits for fuel efficiency format_meanci(mtcars$mpg) #> [1] "_M_ = 20.1, 95% CI [17.9, 22.3]" # Print mean and standard deviation format_meansd(mtcars$mpg) #> [1] "_M_ = 20.1 (_SD_ = 6.0)" # Print mean and standard error of the mean format_meanse(mtcars$mpg) #> [1] "_M_ = 20.1 (_SE_ = 1.1)" # Print mean format_mean(mtcars$mpg) #> [1] "_M_ = 20.1" # Print mean and 95% confidence limits with no label for "95% CI" format_meanci(mtcars$mpg, errorlabel = FALSE) #> [1] "_M_ = 20.1,  [17.9, 22.3]" # Print mean and standard error of the mean as plus/minus interval format_meanse(mtcars$mpg, error = "se", display = "pm") #> [1] "_M_ = 20.1 ± 1.1" # Print mean and 90% confidence limits with units format_meanci(mtcars$mpg, units = "cm", cilevel = 0.9) #> [1] "_M_ = 20.1 cm, 90% CI [18.3, 21.9]" # Print three-digit mean with subscript in LaTeX format_meanerror(mtcars$mpg, digits = 3, subscript = "control", display = "none", type = "latex") #> [1] "$M$$_{control}$ = 20.091"

title: Format numbers — format_num
text: Format numbers

title: Format numbers — format_num
code: format_num(x, digits = 1, pzero = TRUE)

title: Format numbers — format_num
text: x Number digits Number digits decimal pzero Logical indicator whether include leading zero numbers less 1

title: Format numbers — format_num
text: character string formatting number specified number digits decimal.

title: Format numbers — format_num
code: format_num(pi, digits = 2) #> [1] "3.14" format_num(pi, digits = 4) #> [1] "3.1416"

title: Format p-values — format_p
text: format_p() inputs numeric vectors p-values. Cutoffs can set format values less cutoffs (e.g., p < 0.001). default output APA formatted, numbers digits, cutoffs, leading zeros, italics customizable.

title: Format p-values — format_p
code: format_p(   x,   digits = 3,   pzero = FALSE,   label = "p",   italics = TRUE,   type = "md" )

title: Format p-values — format_p
text: x Number representing p-value digits Number digits decimal p-values, ranging 1-5 (also controls cutoff small p-values) pzero Logical indicator whether include leading zero p-values label Character string label p value. Default p. Set label = "" return just formatted p value label operator (=, <, >) italics Logical whether label italicized (p) type Type formatting ("md" = markdown, "latex" = LaTeX)

title: Format p-values — format_p
text: character string includes p p-value formatted Markdown LaTeX. p-value digits cutoff, p < cutoff used.

title: Format p-values — format_p
code: format_p(0.001) #> [1] "_p_ = .001" # Round digits for p-values greater than cutoff format_p(0.111, digits = 2) #> [1] "_p_ = .11" # Default cutoff is p < 0.001 format_p(0.0001) #> [1] "_p_ < .001" # Set cutoff with digits format_p(0.0001, digits = 2) #> [1] "_p_ < .01" # Include leading zero format_p(0.001, pzero = TRUE) #> [1] "_p_ = 0.001" # Return only Bayes factor value (no label) format_p(0.001, label = "") #> [1] ".001"

what: Format numbers in scientific notation — format_scientific
title: Format numbers in scientific notation — format_scientific
text: Format numbers scientific notation

title: Format numbers in scientific notation — format_scientific
code: format_scientific(x, digits = 1, type = "md")

title: Format numbers in scientific notation — format_scientific
text: x Number digits Number digits decimal type Type formatting ("md" = markdown, "latex" = LaTeX)

title: Format numbers in scientific notation — format_scientific
text: character string number scientific notation formatted Markdown LaTeX.

title: Format numbers in scientific notation — format_scientific
code: format_scientific(1111) #> [1] "1.1×10^3^" # Control number of digits after decimal with digits format_scientific(1111, digits = 3) #> [1] "1.111×10^3^"

title: Format t-test statistics — format_ttest
text: format_ttest() can format t-tests generated t.test() wilcox.test() output. default output APA formatted, numbers digits, leading zeros, presence means confidence intervals, italics, degrees freedom, mean labels customizable.

title: Format t-test statistics — format_ttest
code: format_ttest(   x,   digits = 1,   pdigits = 3,   pzero = FALSE,   full = TRUE,   italics = TRUE,   dfs = "par",   mean = "abbr",   type = "md" )

title: Format t-test statistics — format_ttest
text: x t-test object digits Number digits decimal means, confidence intervals, t-statistics pdigits Number digits decimal p-values, ranging 1-5 (also controls cutoff small p-values) pzero Logical indicator whether include leading zero p-values full Logical indicator whether include means confidence intervals just t-statistic p-value italics Logical whether p label italicized dfs Formatting degrees freedom ("par" = parenthetical, "sub" = subscript, "none" = print degrees freedom) mean Formatting mean label ("abbr" = M, "word" = Mean) type Type formatting ("md" = markdown, "latex" = LaTeX)

title: Format t-test statistics — format_ttest
text: character string statistical information formatted Markdown LaTeX.

title: Format t-test statistics — format_ttest
code: # Prepare data mtcars_tt <- t.test(formula = mtcars$mpg ~ mtcars$vs) # Print statistics format_ttest(mtcars_tt) #> [1] "_M_ = -7.9, 95% CI [-11.5, -4.4], _t_(22.7) = -4.7, _p_ < .001" # Change digits format_ttest(mtcars_tt, digits = 2) #> [1] "_M_ = -7.94, 95% CI [-11.46, -4.42], _t_(22.72) = -4.67, _p_ < .001" # Change cutoff digits for p-value format_ttest(mtcars_tt, pdigits = 2) #> [1] "_M_ = -7.9, 95% CI [-11.5, -4.4], _t_(22.7) = -4.7, _p_ < .01" # Add leading zero to p-value and don't print confidence intervals format_ttest(mtcars_tt, pzero = TRUE, full = FALSE) #> [1] "_t_(22.7) = -4.7, _p_ < 0.001"
